text:
Hi, first time BinaryBuilder user here. I'm trying to run a modified build_tarballs.jll from Yggdrasil locally in Julia 1.7, and I've run into two problems
1- I cannot `]add BinaryBuilder` due to unsatisfiable requirements. I've managed to "solve" that by doing `]add BinaryBuilderBase#master BinaryBuilder#master`
2- But when I try to execute my modified `build_tarballs.jl`, I get `*ERROR:* LoadError: UndefVarError: RegistrySpec not defined`. Any clue?

text: not any stable version.  the latest stable version only runs on Julia v1.4-5.  `BinaryBuilder#master` only works in Julia v1.6 (fully works up to the revision mentioned above, partially after that).  note that you also need `BinaryBuildeBase#master` if you go by this route

text: Great!  Yeah, we’re stuck right now because 1.6-beta1 has bugs, but 1.6-beta2 (or 1.6-rc1) will work, it just hasn’t been released yet.  Once it’s released, we’ll have a BB that works on 1.6 properly, and that will be the encouraged version for all to use.

elements.text: Great!  Yeah, we’re stuck right now because 1.6-beta1 has bugs, but 1.6-beta2 (or 1.6-rc1) will work, it just hasn’t been released yet.  Once it’s released, we’ll have a BB that works on 1.6 properly, and that will be the encouraged version for all to use.

text: Well, it finished and it worked beautifully!! I now have a patched OpenBLAS dylib, built on mac through docker/BBuilder magic. I would buy you guys a beer if I could!!

text:
Hi guys. Today I tried to use the dylib I produced with BBuilder. I just tried the following
```julia> dlopen("libopenblas64_.0.3.13.dylib")
ERROR: could not load library "libopenblas64_.0.3.13.dylib"
dlopen(libopenblas64_.0.3.13.dylib, 1): Library not loaded: @rpath/libgfortran.3.dylib```

elements.text: Hi guys. Today I tried to use the dylib I produced with BBuilder. I just tried the following

julia> dlopen("libopenblas64_.0.3.13.dylib")

dlopen(libopenblas64_.0.3.13.dylib, 1): Library not loaded: @rpath/libgfortran.3.dylib

text:
you can see the version of libgfortran version with
```julia> using Base.BinaryPlatforms

julia> HostPlatform()
Linux x86_64 {cxxstring_abi=cxx11, julia_version=1.6.0, libc=glibc, libgfortran_version=5.0.0, libstdcxx_version=3.4.28}

julia> triplet(HostPlatform())
"x86_64-linux-gnu-libgfortran5-libstdcxx28-cxx11-julia_version+1.6.0"```

elements.text: you can see the version of libgfortran version with

julia> using Base.BinaryPlatforms

julia> HostPlatform()
Linux x86_64 {cxxstring_abi=cxx11, julia_version=1.6.0, libc=glibc, libgfortran_version=5.0.0, libstdcxx_version=3.4.28}

julia> triplet(HostPlatform())
"x86_64-linux-gnu-libgfortran5-libstdcxx28-cxx11-julia_version+1.6.0"

text:
I get
```julia> HostPlatform()
macOS x86_64 {julia_version=1.6.0, libgfortran_version=5.0.0, os_version=20.2.0}

julia> triplet(HostPlatform())
"x86_64-apple-darwin20-libgfortran5-julia_version+1.6.0"```

elements.text:
julia> HostPlatform()
macOS x86_64 {julia_version=1.6.0, libgfortran_version=5.0.0, os_version=20.2.0}

julia> triplet(HostPlatform())
"x86_64-apple-darwin20-libgfortran5-julia_version+1.6.0"

text: so you need to build for `x86_64-apple-darwin-libgfortran5`
